html:
3.23.25  5:04 am   i saw your answer abt super technical music theory being confining in comparison to writing based on what naturally feels right and its really similar to my perspective on things. im in hs rn and i hate how black and white the world is. like twice this last week i got marked down for giving an intuitive perspective in like english or history just because the teachers aren't willing to consider ideas outside of the obvious point of view even if i know for a fact the different analysis is still correct. and im just really curious if you ever struggled with this in school as well since so much of your work and personality seems like a natural manifestation of divergence. do u have any advice for thriving when conformity is the key to most success?

      there's a lot to untangle in what you just said, but maybe i'll just point out the biggest thing right at the end which is your claim "conformity is the key to most success" i don't buy that for one second. i don't have the slightest idea where you got that from

3.23.25  4:52 am   Do you ever answer questions with the mindset that you're actually talking face-to-face to the person whose question you're answering? Like, you're at some coffee shop with this person and casually answering the questions they're asking you?

     sure

     If not, why? Do you think asking questions with this mindset might allow us to ask better questions?

     you can only speak for yourself, not necessarily on behalf of other people who may ask questions

      then you're all set

I feel like i enjoying looping certain albums or singles more than just, play the recommended playlist that apple music gave me
but i felt missed out on not enjoying more cool stuff

      right, that can happen. the question is do you wanna do this or not. do you need to do this or not

3.21.25  10:03 pm   in your videos you seem to prefer to move objects instead of manipulating them.

     i'm not even sure what you'd mean by manipulation. if i recall correctly i've done a heck of a lot of manipulation, all throughout my work

      when manipulation happens it is more generally the entire screen instead of individual objects.

     i have no idea what you're talking about

     Can you explain why?

     i cannot explain why you've come to these assumption

3.21.25  9:37 pm   say one day you're just minding your own business and an idea comes to you suddenly. a good idea, one of the better ones you've ever had, and you record the idea down. but the next day you come across this video made a few years ago by this guy you've never even heard of, utilizing exactly the idea that came to you. what would you do in this situation? has this ever happened to you, and if so how frequently does it happen?
adding on, this happened to me just yesterday, which is why I'm asking

      i don't think that has ever happened to me, the closest thing it reminds me of is this: i used a very simple graphic (to represent..... a table? or something) and i put it in a music video. after the music video was released someone informed me that it is exactly the staples logo. i'm well familiar with the staples store, but i've never seen them use that as a logo, it was a new logo for them. i didn't even believe the person who pointed it out to me. then a couple of years later i saw it on a staples truck and sure enough it is exactly the same

3.21.25  9:10 pm   Who should I gamble my savings on in March madness?

      April

      sure

3.21.25  4:53 pm   how do I pass my calculus exam? I am bad at definitions

      i don't know. i didn't do calculus in school. although i have encountered it and used it out of school

3.21.25  3:55 pm   You've mentioned in the past how your work process has 3 roles in it, the idea-creator, the idea-chooser and the idea-finisher.

     it's more roles than that, but that may have been in context of someone's specific question about their own process

      I wanna hear how you think the chooser works, cause oftentimes I find myself with loads of different cool ideas that I want to realize, and what ends up happening is that I get a bunch of unfinished scraps which I don't have the motivation to finish, or which I'm frustatingly unable to figure out how to complete. How does the chooser pick the best ideas so that the creator doesn't get bogged in unhelpful unfinished projects?

     there's no need for the list to bog you down. the list is a well of opportunity. When you the 'procucer' decides "it's time to produce something", the 'selector' then goes into the list, and, by some method, makes a selection, and hands the selection to the producer. And then the producer produces that selection, and the selector does not make a selection until the producer has produced the previous selection. So the only burden, is basically what the selector selects. and yes it's a lot of pressure on the selector to make a selection that everyone is happy about, but there's no need for the LIST to be a burden. it's just the selection that's the burden. but of course it's not a burden, because the fun fact here is that any idea can be worked good. In either case, whether or not you love the selection, your motivation for following through on it might often be the sheer excitement of what you can produce next. i think the power of this method probably comes from a firm agreement you have in the scheduling department to simply continue to produce things diligently one after another, as a coping strategy for the overwhelming potential at stake

3.21.25  3:32 pm   I've always heard that it's "never too late" to learn how to play music... but I've never actually met a musician who didn't start when they were very young? 

      in that case, it's up to you, whether you wanna start
